results.title: Nature of Australia. Parts 1-3
results.brief_description: The first three episodes of the acclaimed nature series “A Separate Creation” tells the story of how the Australian marsupials rose from being primitive insect hunters in the primeval forests of the new vanished super continent of Gondwana, to become the dominant mammal group in Australia. “Seas Under Capricorn” recounts how, following the breakaway from Gondwana 45 million years ago, the island continent came to span both tropical and temperate seas, resulting in the most diverse marine life on Earth. “The Making of the Bush” tells the story of how Australia’s wooded margins came to be dominated by one unique type of tree growing in a great variety of forms - the eucalypt. Rated: G

results.title: Nature of Australia : a portrait of the island continent: the sunburnt country
results.creator_credit: David Parer, ABC-TV (Australia). Natural History Unit and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: In the arid heart of central Australia there is an abundance of wildlife that has uniquely adapted to the harsh conditions. This program looks at shinglebacks, lizards, the gibba bird, marsupial moles, parenti lizard, the thorny devil plus numerous other flora in the region. It also explores the formation of Lake Eyre and what impact the infrequent rain has on the environment when it buckets down. Narrated by Robyn Williams and based on the book written by John Vandenbeld.

results.title: Nature in the garden
results.brief_description: Time-lapse photographic techniques and close-up photography are used in this film to study the lifecycles and habits of a number of insects found in a suburban garden. Illustrates the following: ladybirds attacking aphides; aphis lion eating aphides; new hatched stink bugs; the codlin moth; caterpillar and cabbage moth; camouflage as illustrated by grasshoppers; preying mantis catching and eating flies; spiders hiding and eating moths; leaf-cutting spiders.

results.title: Nature boy (K)
results.brief_description: At the Japanese Kwannon festival people pray for happiness. A young boy is told by a mysterious voice to grasp happiness with his own hands and through his kindness to others he receives fine things - starting with a rice straw, he achieves his wish through perseverance and compassion for others. This is a warm story with delightful puppet animation.

results.title: Nature & nurture interwoven
results.creator_credit: George A. Colburn, Darrel Schwandt, GPN and DLGHS
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
Research in behaviour genetics, the concept of inheritability and data from twin studies are juxtaposed with observations about how parents change the future by changing the circumstances of children’s lives. Observes urban Brazilian children meeting their country cousins in the context of the nature versus nurture debate.

results.title: Nature's strangest creatures
results.creator_credit: Ben Sharpsteen and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Presents Australia’s unusual wildlife at close range. Shots of the giant bat, the lunged fish, the frilled neck lizard, echidna and Tasmanian devil compose the opening sequences; there are glimpses of the emu, the bushy-tailed possum and the koala; and a longer section of the platypus and the kangaroo.

results.title: Nature's plan
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, The Conservation Foundation, John C. Gibbs and George Brewer
results.brief_description: This film describes the water cycle as Nature’s plan for providing all living things with life-giving water. Describes how water form the ocean is drawn into the air by evaporation, formed into clouds, condensed to water, delivered to the earth and returned to the ocean. Natural and time-lapse photography combine with animated drawings to clarify the mechanics of the water cycle and to describe and contrast various water cycle patterns in North America.

results.title: Nature's patterns: Japan's classic beauty
results.brief_description: Shows the close affinity of the Japanese with nature, and how the seasons and natural beauty are reflected in their homes and garden, the clothes and food, their arts and crafts.
results.description: Shows the close affinity of the Japanese with nature, and how the seasons and natural beauty are reflected in their homes and garden, the clothes and food, their arts and crafts.
